Thanks for taking the time to comment. However, I feel the main problem is that you expected to read something else in this post. The conclusions and applied solutions will be discussed in an other post (coming very soon). We’d like to think of this iteration report as some kind of user evaluation report, a post to collect all information about the conducted tests.

This blog post is written is such a way that you could simply skip the ‘results’ section and only read our conclusions, without missing out on critical information. Every problem mentioned in the conclusion section is a summary of some sorts, referring to the numbered results, which we use both as ‘arguments’ for a certain conclusion and as a more in-depth explanation of the problem.

I could imagine that you’re not interested to read all different remarks by our test users, but we chose to use this approach for two reasons.

Firstly, a problem mentioned by ‘just’ one test user can’t be simply ignored. That’s ignoring about 16.7% of our test users… This doesn’t mean we’ll change every little problem found by our testers, we just feel it’s necessary to mention it in this evaluation report, to provide you with an unbiased view of the current status of our design.

Secondly, consistently not mentioning smaller remarks of just one test user could be problematic if the same problem is found by one person during each iteration. That would be quite a few test users overall. By mentioning them in this post, we can easily refer to them if the same problems occur in following iterations.

One among several reasons was that our team wasn’t new to iOS development. We also felt that the concept of our app fits better with mobile devices.

We’ve never planned, nor have any plans, to develop a web version of our app, however, in a more ‘professional’ context, it’s perfectly possible to release the app for other smartphone types as well.

This show/hide solution is meant to be optional, and we’re even ‘hoping’ users won’t find out how to do this the first time they use the app. I know this may sound a bit strange as we’re trying to design a user-friendly interface, but we try to create an app with multiple ‘layers of usage’.

The main functionality, like suggesting and requesting, should be as clear and as easy as possible to use. Showing or hiding own posts is not a primary function as we’re not trying to recreate a mailbox feeling with the activity stream (with seperate incoming and outgoing views), but more something like Twitter or a chatbox, with incoming and outgoing posts mingled (chronologically).

By adding this show/hide option as an extra feature, there is room for the users to ‘explore’ a bit. We consider this to be a playful approach and hope it offers some kind of rewarding, satisfactory feeling when users find out about this feature after their second, third,… time they use the app, triggering some kind of reaction like: “Cool, I didn’t know that was possible too”.

Long story short, no harm’s done if a user won’t find out about this option, but if he does, it could be a motivating, refreshing incentive to keep using the app, showing that the app isn’t ‘shallow’, that it’s has multiple layers of usage.

Maybe Pinterest is relatively young and still needs to go through these upgrades to reduce the chaos.
